article.title: EU agrees to tackle Syria sanctions as Western, Arab leaders meet in Riyadh
content: European foreign ministers have agreed to meet at the end of January to discuss lifting sanctions on Syria as foreign ministers and top diplomats from Western countries and the Middle East convened in Saudi Arabia in the first such regional meeting since the fall of President Bashar al-Assad last month.
Kaja Kallas, the European Unionâ€™s foreign policy chief, said on Sunday that the foreign ministers would convene in Brussels on January 27 to probe how the 27-member bloc might approach the issue.

In Riyadh, she told reporters that the EU wants to see an inclusive government in Syria which shows no signs of â€œradicalisationâ€ and also respects the rights of women and other groups. The bloc can quickly reverse any openings on the issue of sanctions, she stressed.
After Sundayâ€™s talks concluded in Riyadh, Saudi Arabiaâ€™s foreign minister called for the lifting of sanctions on Syria.

â€œWe stressed the importance of lifting unilateral and international sanctions imposed on Syria, as their continuation hinders the aspirations of the Syrian people to achieve development and reconstruction,â€ Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud said.
Syriaâ€™s new Foreign Minister Asaad Hassan al-Shaibani, who has
, attended the talks, alongside foreign ministers from the region including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkiye.
The talks also saw the participation of United States Undersecretary of State John Bass, German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock and British Foreign Secretary David Lammy.

Reporting from Damascus, Al Jazeeraâ€™s Mohammad Jamjoom said the â€œsubstantialâ€ Riyadh diplomatic meeting was more focused on sanctions than a December 14 meeting in Jordanâ€™s Aqaba, which was mostly dealing with ensuring entry of humanitarian aid as Syrians feel the adverse effects.
â€œThese sanctions that have been in place for so long have made it very difficult to import or export raw goods,â€ he said.
â€œThat means prices are always sky-high when it comes to essential goods, including food and medicines. It also means Syrians canâ€™t bring in much fuel, so there are power outages all the time.â€
The conference comes as Syriaâ€™s new administration, led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), has urged the
by the West to help international funding flow to Damascus.

Analyst Rob Geist Pinfold says the Biden administration and European countries are â€œmoving in the direction the HTS wants them to go in terms of removing sanctions, or at least freezing sanctionsâ€.

â€œThe US has said they will freeze sanctions on things like paying public sector workers or providing energy supplies, for example, and thatâ€™s critical,â€ Pinfold, a lecturer at Kingâ€™s College London, told Al Jazeera.

â€œMany of those sanctions were secondary sanctions â€“ meaning that it wasnâ€™t just US citizens or businesses that will be sanctioned for doing business with Syria, but also other countries or third parties as well.â€
The US on Monday issued a
for transactions with governing institutions in Syria for six months after the end of al-Assadâ€™s rule to try to ease the flow of humanitarian assistance.
Germany, Italy and France have in recent days pushed for EU sanctions on Syria to be relaxed, but a final decision could only come from the entire bloc.

Possible priorities for relief include â€œthose sanctions that are hindering the building up of a country, access to banking services and all these thingsâ€, the EUâ€™s Kallas further told reporters in Riyadh.
Germanyâ€™s Baerbock said on Sunday that sanctions against allies of al-Assad, who â€œcommitted serious crimesâ€ during the Syrian war, must remain in place.
â€œBut, Germany proposes to take a smart approach to sanctions, providing relief for the Syrian population. Syrians now need a quick dividend from the transition of power,â€ she added.
A lightning rebel offensive overthrew al-Assad on December 8 and the HTS, which led the advance, set up a caretaker government that appointed al-Shaibani as foreign minister.

The new administration is anxious to get the sanctions lifted because it has to show people that the revolution has improved their lives, according to Galip Dalay, senior consulting fellow at the London-based Chatham House.
He told Al Jazeera that until the government can deliver on points emphasised by the Western parties, â€œany assistance will be quite limited in scope and mostly confined to the humanitarian aspect.
â€œWhat Syria needs is much beyond that and consists of massive reconstruction. So far, we donâ€™t see the Western actors showing full commitment before they see some steps in Syria.â€
The Riyadh meeting was the first to include Syriaâ€™s new rulers and top Western officials and was led by Saudi Arabia.

It followed a meeting of top diplomats from the US, the United Kingdom, France, Germany and the EU held in Rome on Thursday and a landmark meeting Jordan hosted in December, where regional players signalled concerns over Syriaâ€™s new rulers and what they need to do to get international recognition.
article.desc: Top Western and Middle East diplomats and ministers meet to discuss sanctions relief for Syria after al-Assadâ€™s removal.
article.summary: European Union's foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas said on Sunday that the foreign ministers will convene in Brussels on January 27 to probe how the 27-member bloc might approach the issue . The conference comes as Syriaâ€™s new administration, led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) has urged the West to help international funding flow to Damascus. The conference was more focused on sanctions than a December 14 meeting in Jordan

article.title: Jack Smith, who led Trump prosecutions, leaves US Justice Department
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel who led two federal cases against Donald Trump, has left the United States Department of Justice before the
is inaugurated on January 20 for a second term.

The two cases involve Trumpâ€™s alleged mishandling of classified documents after he left the White House and efforts to overturn his 2020 election defeat. Trump was indicted in both cases overseen by Smith.

â€œThe Special Counsel completed his work and submitted his final confidential report on January 7, 2025, and separated from the Department on January 10,â€ officials said in the document submitted to US District Judge Aileen Cannon, urging her last week not to extend her order blocking the release of Smithâ€™s final report.
The statement on Smith was a footnote in the filing to Cannon as she mulls whether to maintain a hold on the special counselâ€™s report on two cases.
A former war crimes prosecutor, Smith was appointed in November 2022 â€“ nearly two years after the
â€“ to lead the Justice Departmentâ€™s twin ongoing investigations into Trump.

He brought two of the four criminal cases Trump faced after leaving office but saw them grind to a halt after a Trump-appointed judge in Florida dismissed one and the US Supreme Court found that former presidents have sweeping immunity from prosecution for official acts. Neither case went to trial.

After Trump defeated Democratic Vice President Kamala Harris in the November 5 election, Smith dropped both cases, citing a longstanding Justice Department rule against prosecuting sitting presidents. In asking courts to dismiss the charges, Smithâ€™s team defended the merits of the cases they had brought, signalling only that Trumpâ€™s impending return to the White House made them untenable.

Smithâ€™s departure is another marker of the collapse of the criminal cases against Trump, which could end without any legal consequences for the incoming president and led to a backlash that helped fuel his political comeback.

Meanwhile, Trump, who has frequently called Smith â€œderangedâ€ and said he would fire him immediately upon taking office, has suggested that he may pursue retribution against Smith and others who investigated him once he returns to office.
article.desc: A former war crimes prosecutor, Smith was appointed in November 2022 â€“ nearly two years after the US Capitol attack.
article.summary: Jack Smith, the special counsel who led two federal cases against Donald Trump, has left the U.S. Department of Justice . The two cases involve Trumpâ€™s alleged mishandling of classified documents after he left the White House and efforts to overturn his 2020 election defeat . Trump was indicted in both cases overseen by Smith . Smith was appointed in November 2022 â€“ nearly two years after the Justice Department. He brought two of the four criminal cases

article.title: Myanmarâ€™s rebels liberate territory â€“ administrating it is the next battle
content: Thaw Hti was a tiny speck amid a march of hundreds of thousands that snaked its way through the streets of Yangon in 2021, demanding a return to democracy after the Myanmar
â€œWe had signboards and they had guns,â€ she said, recounting with bitterness the events of March 2021.
In the intervening four years, much has changed for Thaw Hti and her generation in Myanmar.
After the military
in bloody crackdowns on those pro-democracy protests,
to territory controlled by ethnic armed groups in Myanmarâ€™s border regions with Thailand, India and China.
Thaw Hti went, too.
Ethnically part Karen, her choice was obvious.

She sought refuge with the Karen National Union â€“ Myanmarâ€™s oldest ethnic armed group, which has been fighting for political autonomy for the Karen people since the 1940s in Myanmarâ€™s eastern Karen State, also known as Kayin State.
Speaking during an interview with Al Jazeera in Karen State recently, Thaw Hti told how she was so furious at the military for seizing power that she wanted to become a
All new arrivals in KNU territory had to undergo a survival course, which included weapons training, marching long distances in rugged terrain and basic self-defence.
Firing a gun, Thaw Hti remembers, gave her a feeling of strength after powerlessly watching the military massacre her fellow protesters.
Now, her face crinkles into a huge smile when she says: â€œI love gunsâ€.
But, being short and slight, she struggled to complete even the basic survival course and knew that she would not pass the KNUâ€™s real military training.
â€œI came here to join the revolution but as a woman, there are more barriers,â€ she said.
â€œMentally I want to do it but physically I canâ€™t.â€

With a background in education and the ability to speak Karen, Thaw Hti and her husband instead opened a school accredited by the KNU where they teach more than 100 children who have been displaced by conflict.

The school is concealed in the forest in eastern Myanmar because of the militaryâ€™s tendency to launch air strikes on the Karenâ€™s parallel public services â€“ including schools and hospitals. The bombing aims to destroy the emerging administrative structures that lend legitimacy to Karen autonomy.

Unlike schools under the military regimeâ€™s control, Thaw Hti explained that her school teaches children in the Karen language and teaches a Karen-centred version of Myanmar history that includes the decades of oppression the Karen faced, which is often left out of official narratives.

The Karen have fought for their autonomy for decades, but as newer, pro-democracy forces team up with ethnic armed groups, the Karenâ€™s long-simmering conflict with Myanmarâ€™s military â€“ a majority, ethnic Bamar force â€“ has exploded in intensity.

Particularly in the last year, the military has lost huge swaths of territory in the borderlands â€“ including nearly all of Rakhine State in the west and northern Shan State in the east â€“ as well as large chunks of Kachin State in the north, and also more of Karen State.
But as fighters take more and more territory, they are faced with a new challenge: administering it.
Seized from the military in March, Kyaikdon in Karen State has been spared the devastating air strikes that have plagued other large towns won by resistance forces.

During Al Jazeeraâ€™s recent visit to Kyaikdon, the townâ€™s restaurants were filled with civilians and Karen troops eating Burmese curry. Shops were open and selling household goods and traditional Karen fabrics, while the main road was backed up with traffic.
Soe Khant, the townâ€™s 33-year-old KNU-appointed administrator, said he had big plans for the liberated territory.

â€œI would like to finish public works, get electricity and water running and clean up the plastic and the overgrown areas,â€ said Soe Khant, who was officially appointed interim administrator, with an election planned after one year.
He agrees with eventually being popularly elected, rather than appointed.
â€œIf itâ€™s what the people want, I will take the position. If they choose somebody else, I will pass it on,â€ he told Al Jazeera.
Soe Khant said the military regime â€œtotally neglected the people of this townâ€.
Growing up in Kyaikdon, Soe Khant told how he would hike to the top of a hill near the town with a friend.
From there they would sketch the cluster of buildings around the dusty main road, the winding river that nourishes the farms, and the nearby mountain range that forms the border with Thailand.
When he got older, he turned to photography, making a living from wedding shoots.
But when the COVID-19 pandemic hit Myanmar in 2020, he answered another calling, launching a social welfare organisation.
After the military coup, the situation worsened further.
â€œThe healthcare system broke down, so my friends and I volunteered to help take care of people,â€ he said.
While Soe Khant is relatively new to the business of running a parallel administration, the KNU has been doing this for decades â€“ albeit usually in smaller, rural pockets of territory.
Kawkareik townshipâ€™s secretary Mya Aye served as a village tract leader for 12 years before being elected to his current role, the third most senior in the township.
He told Al Jazeera how years of war and a lack of human resources had hampered the local economy and undermined the KNUâ€™s ability to provide public services.

â€œThere are no factories, no industry, you canâ€™t work here to support your family,â€ he said, explaining that because of the conflict and hardships, young people would move to live in nearby Thailand.
But the military regimeâ€™s cruelty is often its own worst enemy.
It has inspired more fervent resistance and driven
into the arms of its enemies.
Â
Former Myanmar police officer Win Htun, 33, joined the KNU rather than follow orders to arrest and abuse pro-democracy activists.
â€œI always wanted to be a police officer since I was young,â€ Win Htun said.
â€œI believed the police were good and tried to help people,â€ he said, adding that the reality was a culture of corruption, discrimination and impunity.
Win Htun, who is a member of the Bamar ethnic majority in Myanmar, said police authorities treated their Karen colleagues very unfairly.

â€œIf any of them made a small mistake they gave them a very harsh punishment,â€ he said, recounting how one Karen officer returned to the barracks one hour late and was put in a prison cell for 24 hours.
Win Htun said he submitted resignation letters multiple times in his 10 years of police service. Each time they were rejected.
After the 2021 coup, he fled with his wife and daughter to Karen-controlled territory, where he was subjected to a thorough background check and a â€œtrust-buildingâ€ observation period.
Now he is fully integrated into the KNUâ€™s police force.

Reacting to the militaryâ€™s brutality and a sense that the revolution is on the verge of victory, younger educated professionals, like Thaw Hti, and people with years of government service, such as Win Htun, have come to fill human resource gaps in the administration of newly liberated areas.
But most thought the fight to topple the military would take just a few months or, at most, a few years.
Despite a string of defeats and other unprecedented setbacks, the military has managed to hold on.
â€œItâ€™s like running on a treadmill,â€ Thaw Hti said of the revolutionâ€™s gains but continued shortcomings.
â€œWe feel like we are going so fast, but we donâ€™t go very far,â€ she said.
article.desc: Al Jazeera visits areas liberated from the military in Karen State where establishing a civil administration is the next task for pro-democracy forces.
article.summary: Thaw Hti was a tiny speck amid a march of hundreds of thousands that snaked its way through the streets of Yangon in 2021 . â€˜We had signboards and they had guns,â€™ she said, recounting with bitterness the events of March 2021 . She sought refuge with the Karen National Union â€“ Myanmarâ€™s oldest ethnic armed group. It has been fighting for political autonomy for the Karen people since the 1940

article.title: Russia claims to have seized new villages in eastern Ukraine
content: Russia claims it has captured two villages in eastern Ukraine where its forces have been steadily advancing for months, as Ukraineâ€™s president urged allies to deliver all the weapons they have promised to send to Kyiv.

The Russian Defence Ministry said on Sunday that soldiers have captured the village of Yantarne in the eastern Donetsk region, about 10km (six miles) southwest of Kurakhove, a key logistics hub that Moscow claimed to have seized last week â€“ a day after Russiaâ€™s army said it had also taken new territory northwest of Kurakhove.
The Defence Ministry added that soldiers had also captured the village of Kalinove in the northeastern Kharkiv region.
The village is on the western bank of the Oskil River, which for a long time formed the front line between the two armies in the region.
A Ukrainian official, quoted by the AFP news agency, said on Thursday that Russian forces had managed to establish a bridgehead on the western bank after crossing the river.
Russiaâ€™s army has spent months making attempts to cross the river, which also cuts through Kupiansk, a city recaptured by Ukraine in its 2022 counteroffensive.

Separately, the Russian Defence Ministry said that over the past 24 hours, Russiaâ€™s forces have carried out strikes on Ukrainian military airfields, personnel and vehicles in 139 locations using the air force, drones, missiles and artillery.
Ukrainian air defences downed 60 out of 94 drones launched by Russia overnight, according to the Ukrainian air force.
It said that 34 drones were â€œlostâ€, in reference to Ukraineâ€™s use of electronic warfare to redirect Russian drones.
Falling drone fragments damaged houses in the Kharkiv, Sumy and Poltava regions, but no one was hurt, the air force said.

In the southern Kherson region, three people were injured by drones on Sunday, regional authorities said, and about 23,000 households were left without electricity after Russian shelling damaged power equipment in the city.
The attack targeted the Dniprovskyi district along the Dnipro River, an area of Kherson that is regularly shelled by Russian forces on the opposite bank.
Khersonâ€™s governor, Oleksandr Prokudin, said Kherson city and about 50 settlements in the surrounding region had been shelled by Russian forces over the past 24 hours.

â€œThe Russian military shelled social infrastructure and residential areas of the regionâ€™s settlements, in particular, damaging two multistorey buildings and eight private houses,â€ Prokudin said on Telegram.
In the Russian-controlled section of the Kherson region, a Ukrainian drone attacked a car, killing a 76-year-old woman outside her house, Russian-installed Governor Vladimir Saldo said on Telegram.
In a statement on Sunday, Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy called on allies to honour all promises to supply Ukraine with weapons, including those to counter Russian air attacks.
Zelenskyy said that over the past week, Russian forces had launched hundreds of attacks on Ukraine and nearly 700 aerial bombs and more than 600 attack drones were used.
â€œEvery week, the Russian war continues only because the Russian army retains its ability to terrorise Ukraine and exploit its superiority in the sky,â€ Zelenskyy said on the Telegram messaging app.

â€œThe decisions made at the NATO summit in Washington, as well as those adopted during the Ramstein meetings regarding air defences for Ukraine, have still not been fully implemented,â€ Zelenskyy said.
Ukraineâ€™s leader this week said he had discussed with partners and the United States the possibility of granting Ukraine licences to produce air defence systems and missiles.

Meanwhile, Russian officials said an emergency task force arrived in Russiaâ€™s southern Krasnodar region on Sunday as an oil spill in the Kerch Strait from two storm-stricken tankers continues to spread a month after it was first detected.

The task force, which includes Emergency Situations Minister Alexander Kurenkov, was set up after Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday called on authorities to ramp up the response to the spill, calling it â€œone of the most serious environmental challenges we have faced in recent yearsâ€.

Kurenkov said that â€œthe most difficult situationâ€ had developed near the port of Taman in the Krasnodar region, where fuel oil continues to leak into the sea from the damaged part of the Volgoneft-239 tanker.
Kurenkov was quoted as saying by Russian state news agency RIA Novosti that the remaining oil will be pumped out of the tankerâ€™s stern.

In response to Putinâ€™s call for action, Ukraineâ€™s Foreign Ministry spokesman Heorhii Tykhyi accused Russia of â€œbeginning to demonstrate its alleged â€˜concernâ€™ only after the scale of the disaster became too obvious to conceal its terrible consequencesâ€.

â€œRussiaâ€™s practice of first ignoring the problem, then admitting its inability to solve it, and ultimately leaving the entire Black Sea region alone with the consequences is yet another proof of its international irresponsibility,â€ Tykhyi said on Friday.

The Kerch Strait is an important global shipping route, providing passage from the inland Sea of Azov to the Black Sea. It has also been a key point of conflict between Russia and Ukraine after Moscow annexed the peninsula in 2014.
In 2016, Ukraine took Moscow to the Permanent Court of Arbitration, where it accused Russia of trying to seize control of the area illegally. In 2021, Russia closed the strait for several months.
Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to Zelenskyyâ€™s office, described the oil spill last month as a â€œlarge-scale environmental disasterâ€ and called for additional sanctions on Russian tankers.
article.desc: The Ministry of Defence in Russia says its soldiers captured Yantarne in the eastern Donetsk region and Kalinove in the northeastern Kharkiv region.
article.summary: Russia claims it has captured two villages in eastern Ukraine where its forces have been advancing for months . The Russian Defence Ministry said on Sunday that soldiers have captured the village of Yantarne in the eastern Donetsk region . The village is on the western bank of the Oskil River, which for a long time formed the front line between the two armies in the region. Russiaâ€™s army has spent months making attempts to cross the river

article.title: How strategic is Wad Madani city, retaken by Sudanese army?
content: PeoplSudanâ€™s army has recaptured Wad Madani, a strategically important city some 200km (124 miles) southeast of the capital Khartoum, in a major blow to the paramilitary

â€œThe leadership of the Armed Forces congratulates our people on the entry of our forces into Wad Madani this morning. They are now working to clean up the remaining rebel pockets inside the city,â€ an army statement read.
This comes as the army

into the countryâ€™s second-largest city Omdurman last week after making steady gains in recent months. Wad Madani â€“ the crossroads of key supply highways linking several states â€“ had been under RSF control since December 2023.
RSF leader Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, however, insisted that the battle was not over. â€œToday we lost a round, we did not lose the battle,â€ said Dagalo, who is also known as Hemedti.
Since fighting erupted in April 2023 between the army and the RSF over control of this North African nation, more than 12 million people have been displaced, creating one of the
So how significant is the recapture of Wad Madani by the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF)? Can the army repeat its recent success as it aims to recapture territories still under RSF control?
The city is the capital of Gezira state, located in the centre of the country and south of Khartoum.
According to Al Jazeeraâ€™s Hiba Morgan, whoever has control of the agricultural and trading hub has easier access to other parts of the country.

â€œWhen the RSF took over Wad Madani in December 2023, that gave it the ability to be able to move to other parts of the country such as Sennar in the southeast, Blue Nile in the east, and the White Nile in the south as well,â€ Morgan said, reporting from the Sudanese capital.

The city is also at â€œa very important pointâ€ through which supplies and other â€œlogistical arrangementsâ€ can be made into the capital, according to Hamid Khalafallah, a Sudan policy analyst and PhD candidate at the University of Manchester.
â€œWhoever controls Madani [has] a lot more flexibility in terms of different stuff into Khartoum and out of Khartoum,â€ Khalafallah told Al Jazeera.
In the early days of the conflict, before the RSF took over, the city was a safe haven for displaced families.

Since the RSFâ€™s takeover, it has been one of the sites of the paramilitary forceâ€™s bloodiest attacks on civilians, as well as the burning of fields, looting of hospitals and markets, and flooding of irrigation ditches.
No, the RSF still retains control of most of the state, as well as nearly all of Sudanâ€™s western Darfur region and large parts of the countryâ€™s south.
The armyâ€™s takeover of the strategic city follows its bolstered campaign to retake Gezira in recent months, after retaking Sennar state in the south.
The army was helped by the turn of events in October, when RSFâ€™s top commander in the state defected to the SAF. The commanderâ€™s troops took part in Saturdayâ€™s operations.
Last week, the army
in the second-largest city Omdurman, capturing several areas from the RSF.
This represents a significant turn of events in the war and another blow to the RSF, which has had an upper hand against the military in the nearly two-year conflict.
The armyâ€™s capture will allow it to access other parts of the country that the RSF will now be cut off from, such as the Sennar, Blue Nile, and White Nile states.

â€œNow that [the RSF] lost that territory, that progress that it was able to make will not be possible, and its forces in those areas will be trapped between forces of the Sudanese army,â€ said Morgan.
â€œWad Madani is also where the armyâ€™s first infantry division is located, so that is going to give the army a morale boost,â€ she added.

When the RSF took over the city, there were a lot of complaints among officers and soldiers that the leadership was not meeting the standards of the Sudanese army and that there should be a replacement of the leadership, explained Morgan.

â€œNow that Wad Madani is back under the control of the Sudanese army, the army is likely to gain â€“ especially its leadership â€“ is likely to gain more support, not just from the soldiers and officers but also from the Sudanese citizens as well,â€ she said.

Additionally, the cityâ€™s recapture could aid in Sudanâ€™s hunger crisis, as the state is home to Sudanâ€™s most fertile lands and agriculture schemes â€“ with most farming prohibited under the RSF, said Khalafallah, the researcher.
â€œNow there will be room for people to grow, and to farm, and for food to be produced, and so on, to address Sudanâ€™s unfolding famine and food security crisis,â€ he said.

The turn of events may also offer long-awaited respite to the cityâ€™s residents, who â€œhave been experiencing the most horrific human rights violations and atrocities committed by the [Rapid] Support Forcesâ€, Khalafallah said.

Still, there has been a pattern of the army targeting pro-democracy activists in the cities they have already recaptured, Khalafallah warned, which could be a worrying development if repeated in Wad Madani.

Beyond Wad Madani, the Sudanese army also controls the north and east of the country, as well as parts of the capital. The map below indicates areas of control between the SAF and the RSF, as of October 2024.

In Wad Madani, Sudanese troops garbed in camo-print uniforms waved their rifles in the air as they rode through town on the back of their trucks, flashing smiles after claiming to â€œliberateâ€ the city, social media footage verified by Al Jazeera shows.
The local resistance committee, one of hundreds of pro-democracy volunteer groups across the country coordinating front-line aid, hailed the advance as an end to â€œthe tyrannyâ€ of the RSF.
Meanwhile, eyewitnesses in army-controlled cities across Sudan reported dozens jubilantly celebrating in the streets.
In the Red Sea-flanked city of
, boisterous crowds waved the Sudanese flag in celebration, verified videos also showed, following the news that
from the RSFâ€™s control.
In Omdurman, chants of â€œone army, one peopleâ€ broke out, an eyewitness told the AFP news agency.
article.desc: The armyâ€™s recapture of the agricultural and trading hub will mean the opposition Rapid Support Forces (RSF) will be cut off from various parts of the country.
article.summary: Wad Madani is a strategically important city 200km (124 miles) southeast of the capital Khartoum . The city is the capital of Gezira state, located in the centre of the country and south of the Sudanese capital . More than 12 million people have been displaced since fighting erupted in April 2023 between the army and RSF over control of this North African nation. The army has made steady gains in recent months.

article.title: Sense of impunity â€˜absoluteâ€™: The NGO holding Israeli soldiers to account
content: Israeli officials are concerned about their soldiers being arrested after fighting in Gaza after a soldier fled Brazil to avoid being questioned over alleged war crimes he committed in Gaza and filmed for social media.
The Belgium-based
(HRF) is the force behind this international effort for accountability.
Formed just five months ago, HRF has pulled together lawyers and activists from around the world to prepare cases, primarily based on social media content shared by Israeli soldiers themselves.
Israeli reservist Yuval Vagdani was among the first of what HRF founder and Chair Dyab Abou Jahjah says will be many soldiers accused of war crimes.

Speaking to the Israeli media on Wednesday after being â€œforcedâ€ to cut his â€œdream tripâ€ to Brazil short, Vagdani said finding himself subject to an overseas war crimes investigation after having filmed himself blowing up peopleâ€™s homes in Gaza â€œfelt a little like a bullet in the heartâ€.

According to local media, Israelâ€™s Ministry of Foreign Affairs had played a critical role in helping Vagdani evade investigation and potential prosecution for war crimes, first arranging for him to be smuggled into Argentina, and from there to the United States, before eventually leaving for Israel.
Israeli authorities and media have issued guidelines to soldiers on
and
while on deployment.
No response has been received to Al Jazeeraâ€™s query as to whether these extra measures include training for reservists on what might constitute a war crime.

After 15 months of Israeli soldiers proudly sharing videos of themselves committing potential war crimes in Gaza, HRF had plenty of evidence to use when seeking their prosecution under international and domestic law.
The videos and stills show soldiers forcing
, abusing captives,
and vandalising homes and

â€œThis is about being accountable to the law,â€ Abou Jahjah said. â€œIf individual soldiers feel they havenâ€™t committed a war crime, thatâ€™s fine. Letâ€™s hear their case. Itâ€™s in the interests of everyone to do so.â€

Hind Rajab is the name of a five-year-old girl who was killed in a car in Gaza by Israel as she pleaded on the phone for three hours for help, surrounded by members of her dead family and in sight of the Palestinian paramedics who were also killed as they attempted to reach her.
So far, the foundation named after her has filed more than 1,000 cases to the international court.

HRF lawyers and online activists trawl through mountains of images and videos submitted to them online to verify and geolocate each one, check its metadata and verify its chain of custody, from the soldier filming it through to HRF, Abou Jahjah explained.

Where the perpetrator is a dual national, HRF seeks prosecution under the second countryâ€™s existing laws on war crimes and in the case of sole Israeli citizens, collate legal files, which are then filed as evidence with the International Criminal Court (ICC).

Predictably, HRFâ€™s work has been met with fierce criticism in Israel, with some claiming that these legal procedures are â€œdoxxingâ€ (the unauthorised publication of individual identities) of soldiers who filmed themselves.

Abou Jahjah has also been personally threatened by Israeli Minister of Diaspora Affairs Amichai Chikli, who â€“ alluding to the attacks on Hezbollahâ€™s membersâ€™ communication systems in September 2024 â€“ told him to â€œwatch your pagerâ€.
â€œI donâ€™t really care,â€ Abou Jahjah said, â€œIâ€™ve been at this for many years and, when you compare it to whatâ€™s happening in Gaza, threats against me donâ€™t really amount to much.â€
HRF also maintains a catalogue of what it describes as the â€œperpetrators, accomplices and incitersâ€ it is seeking investigations against for war crimes.
â€œTheyâ€™re proud of these acts,â€ Milena Ansari of Human Rights Watch said from Jerusalem of the potential war crimes broadcast by soldiers across social media.
â€œPutting it online both adds to the dehumanisation of Palestinians as well as provides cause for actual celebration,â€ she told Al Jazeera.

â€œThe sense of impunity is absolute â€¦ Itâ€™s always been there, especially with regard to Israeli actions in the occupied West Bank, but itâ€™s increased significantly since October 2023 [when Israelâ€™s war on Gaza began].â€

Many in Israel regard the cases against reservists as unjust and a continuation of centuries of anti-Semitism, feelings claimed and weaponised by the Israeli state, political scientist Ori Goldberg said from Tel Aviv.
â€œThings are deteriorating within Israel,â€ Goldberg said. â€œYou canâ€™t engage in a genocide for 15 months and expect anything else. Israel has been fundamentally changed.

â€œPeople donâ€™t regard Palestinians as even human now, if they ever really did. To most people, Palestinians arenâ€™t even vermin. Vermin has to be killed. Palestinians are less than that,â€ he said.
In that context, a few soldiers â€œletting off steamâ€ during a war that none feels responsible for, where the only victims were Palestinian, was understandable to many within Israel, Goldberg said
â€œTheyâ€™re spinning this as the world against Israel,â€ Goldberg said of the government and media response to the numerous investigations and prosecutions thought to be under way.
â€œItâ€™s the persecution of the Jews, all over again,â€ he said.

â€œMost people donâ€™t even feel that Gaza has anything to do with them,â€ Goldberg continued, â€œOn the one hand, we continue to bomb it, on the other, we feel weâ€™re unaccountable for what goes on there.â€
article.desc: The Hind Rajab Foundation is using Israeli soldiersâ€™ own social media footage as evidence for war crimes investigations.
article.summary: Belgium-based HRF is the force behind this international effort for accountability . It has pulled together lawyers and activists from around the world to prepare cases based on social media content shared by Israeli soldiers . Israeli reservist Yuval Vagdani was among the first of what HRF founder and Chair Dyab Abou Jahjah says will be many soldiers accused of war crimes . The videos and stills show soldiers forcing abusing captives, abusing captives

article.title: Which Hollywood stars have lost their homes in the California wildfires?
content: Since Tuesday,
have ravaged different neighbourhoods in California, especially around the Los Angeles area.
The California wildfires have killed
and destroyed some 10,000 homes and structures, local officials have said.
Los Angeles is home to Hollywood, Americaâ€™s entertainment hub, and to many Hollywood celebrities. Many of
lost their houses in the fires.
The Sunset Fire, which broke out on Wednesday about 6pm (02:00 GMT), particularly affected Hollywood Hills. Its cause is under investigation, but it ravaged 17 hectares (42 acres) of land.
By midday on Thursday, Mayor Karen Bass reported that the Sunset Fire was contained.

The 76-year-old American comedian and star of the 1980s iconic movie, When Harry Met Sally, lost the home that he has owned since 1979 in Pacific Palisades. Crystal and his wife, Janice, expressed sadness over losing the house in which they had raised their children and grandchildren. He said in a statement to CNN on Wednesday: â€œWe are heartbroken of course but with the love of our children and friends we will get through this.â€

The Mad Max star told NewsNation that his house had been destroyed while he was filming in Austin, Texas. He said: â€œItâ€™s kind of devastating. Itâ€™s emotional. You know, you live there for a long time, and you had all your stuff. Iâ€™ve been relieved from the burden of my stuff, because itâ€™s all in cinders.â€
A spokesman for the veteran actor was quoted by The Hollywood Reporter saying his home in Malibu had been burned down in the Palisades Fire.

The television personality and socialiteâ€™s Malibu beach mansion has burned down, also in the Palisades Fire. In posts on Instagram and X, Hilton wrote that she had watched the disaster unfold on live television. â€œThe heartbreak is truly indescribable,â€ she wrote in an X post.

Iâ€™m standing here in what used to be our home, and the heartbreak is truly indescribable.ğŸ’”ğŸ¥º When I first saw the news, I was in complete shockâ€”I couldnâ€™t process it. But now, standing here and seeing it with my own eyes, it feels like my heart has shattered into a millionâ€¦
â€” Paris Hilton (@ParisHilton)
The Princess Bride actor also announced that his family home had been destroyed. He
his Instagram followers: â€œSadly, we did lose our home but we are grateful to have survived this truly devastating fire.â€
The This Is Us star told

that her family had evacuated their home in Altadena before it was badly damaged in the Eaton Fire. â€œI love you, Altadena. Grateful for my family and pets getting out last night before it was too lateâ€¦ Honestly, Iâ€™m in shock and feeling numb for all so many have lost, including my family. My childrenâ€™s school is gone. Our favorite restaurants, leveled.â€
Another This Is Us star

that he and his pregnant wife, Jarah Mariano, had lost their Malibu home. He said: â€œI think thereâ€™s a kind of shock moment where youâ€™re going, â€˜Oh, this is real and this is happening,â€™ and then at a certain point, we just turn it off. Itâ€™s like, what good is it to continue watching, you know. We kind of accepted the loss.â€
Media outlets also reported that the homes of
, known for television show Gossip Girl and her husband,
from The OC;
from Top Gun Maverick; and
from Scary Movie had also been damaged or destroyed by the fires. However, they have yet to publicly comment. The star of the Schittâ€™s Creek comedy series,

, who is also honorary mayor of the Palisades, was reported by local media as having lost his $3.9m property. His son, Dan Levy, posted: â€œHeartbroken for my family, my friends, and the people of LA affected by the catastrophic fires.â€ However, Eugene Levy himself has not confirmed the loss of his home.

Other celebrities announced that they have evacuated their homes. This includes model Chrissy Teigen and her husband, John Legend; James Woods; comedian Marc Maron; and actor Mark Hamill from Star Wars.
With firefighting resources running thin, residents in the close-knit suburb of Altadena are concerned that the resources will be allocated to neighbourhoods where A-listers reside, Reuters reported.

â€œYouâ€™re going to have some folks who are not going to get as much as they deserve, and some folks who may get more than actually they need,â€ Inez Moore, a lecturer at California State University told Reuters. Mooreâ€™s family home in Altadena was destroyed in the Eaton Fire.
Social media users have been sharing images of what looks like the iconic Hollywood sign engulfed in flames.
The sign is located in Griffith Park, which has been closed as a safety measure.

However, from what we know so far, the sign is secure and has not caught fire. Jeff Zarrinnam, chair of the Hollywood Sign Trust, told Reuters news agency via email on Thursday that the sign had not been affected.
Reuters reported that the images had likely been generated by AI software.
article.desc: Celebrities have lost homes but a social media post showing the Hollywood sign burning proved to be false.
article.summary: The Sunset Fire, which broke out on Wednesday about 6pm (02:00 GMT), particularly affected Hollywood Hills . By midday on Thursday, Mayor Karen Bass reported that the Sunset Fire was contained . Paris Hilton's Malibu beach mansion has burned down, also in the Palisades Fire . The Princess Bride actor also announced that his home in Malibu had been burned down. The Mad Max star said his house had been destroyed in the fire

article.title: Guantanamo at 23: Whatâ€™s next for the â€˜lawlessâ€™ detention facility?
content: Â The detention facility at
, Cuba, turns 23 on Saturday.
For Mansoor Adayfi, a former inmate at the prison, the anniversary marks 23 years of â€œinjustice, lawlessness, abuse of power, torture and indefinite detentionâ€.

Only 15 prisoners remain at the United States military prison, known as Gitmo, which once held about 800 Muslim men â€” a dwindling number that gives advocates hope that the facility will eventually be shut down, turning the page on the dark chapter of history it represents.

But Adayfi, who now serves as a coordinator for the Guantanamo Project at the advocacy group CAGE International, says truly closing down Gitmo means delivering justice to its current and former detainees.

â€œThe United States must acknowledge its wrongdoing, must issue a formal, official apology to the victims, to the survivors,â€ Adayfi told Al Jazeera. â€œThere must be reparation, compensation and accountability.â€
Guantanamo opened in 2002 to house prisoners from the so-called â€œwar on terrorâ€, a reaction to the attacks on September 11, 2001, in the US.

Detainees were arrested in countries across the world on suspicions of ties to al-Qaeda and other groups. Many endured horrific torture at secret detention facilities, known as black sites, before being transferred to Guantanamo.

At Gitmo, detainees had few legal rights. Even those cleared for release through Guantanamoâ€™s alternative justice system, known as military commissions, remained imprisoned for years with no recourse to challenge their detention.
And so, the prison has become synonymous with the US governmentâ€™s worst abuses in the post-9/11 era.
In recent weeks, the administration of outgoing President Joe Biden has accelerated the transfer of inmates out of Guantanamo, ahead of the end of his term on January 20.
On Monday, the US government freed 11
and resettled them in Oman. Last month, two inmates were transferred to Tunisia
Daphne Eviatar, director of the Security with Human Rights (SWHR) programme at Amnesty International USA, said closing down the facility is possible.
She said the remaining detainees could be transferred to other countries or to the US, where they would go through the American justice system.

Congress imposed a ban in 2015 on transferring Gitmo prisoners to US soil. But Eviatar believes the White House can work with lawmakers to lift the prohibition, especially with so few prisoners left at the facility.
â€œItâ€™s a symbol of lawlessness, of Islamophobia,â€ Eviatar said of Guantanamo.

â€œItâ€™s a complete violation of human rights. For the United States, which has detained so many people for so long without rights, without charge or trial, it is just horrific. And the fact that itâ€™s ongoing today, 23 years later, is insane.â€

Barack Obama made closing down the prison one of his top promises when he was running for president in 2008, but after taking office, his plans faced strong Republican opposition. Towards the end of his second term, Obama expressed regret
to shut down the facility early in his presidency.
Of the 15 remaining Gitmo inmates, three are eligible for release, according to the Pentagon. Three others can go in front of Guantanamoâ€™s Periodic Review Board, which assesses
are safe to transfer.
â€œWeâ€™re still hopeful that President Biden can transfer more detainees out before he leaves office,â€ Eviatar told Al Jazeera.
While President-elect Donald Trump has previously pledged to keep the prison open, Eviatar said he may view the facility as inefficient.
But the Friends Committee on National Legislation (FCNL), a Quaker social justice advocacy group, underscored the urgency for Biden to act before Trump takes office.

â€œWith President-elect Trump strongly opposed to closing Guantanamo, the need to President Biden to shut the prison down is more urgent than ever,â€ Devra Baxter, a programme assistant for militarism and human rights at FCNL, said in a statement.
â€œClosing Guantanamo will only happen through the transfer of the final three men who have yet to be charged with a crime and finalizing plea deals with those who have.â€

However, rather than completing plea deals for the inmates, Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin has sought to nix agreements for three 9/11 suspects, which had been reached with military prosecutors to spare the prisoners the death penalties, in exchange for guilty pleas.
Now courts
the validity of the agreements and Austinâ€™s veto against them.
Eviatar said Austinâ€™s push to scuttle the plea deals amounts to political interference.

â€œItâ€™s a very strange situation. I donâ€™t understand why the Biden administration, which says it wanted to close Guantanamo, would then have the secretary of defence come in and stop the plea agreements. It makes no sense.â€
CAGEâ€™s Adayfi said the debacle over the plea agreements shows that there is no functioning justice system at Guantanamo.
â€œItâ€™s a big joke,â€ he said. â€œThereâ€™s no justice
. Thereâ€™s no law. There is absolutely nothing. Itâ€™s it is one of the biggest human rights violations in the 21st century.â€
Adayfi added that the US can have its ideals about freedom, democracy and human rights or Guantanamo, but not both.
â€œI believe they have Guantanamo,â€ he said.
article.desc: With 15 inmates remaining, advocates urge Biden to release more Gitmo detainees before he leaves office on January 20.
article.summary: Only 15 prisoners remain at the U.S. military prison, known as Gitmo, which once held about 800 Muslim men . Mansoor Adayfi, a former inmate at the prison, says truly closing down Gitmo means delivering justice to its current and former detainees . â€œThe United States must acknowledge its wrongdoing, must issue a formal, official apology to the victims, to the survivors,â€ AdayFi told Al Jazeera

article.title: â€˜Much more persecutionâ€™: Venezuela braces for Nicolas Maduroâ€™s inauguration
content: Jesus Medina Ezaine had already spent 16 months in a Venezuelan military prison, accused of crimes he said were related to his work as a photojournalist.
But another prison stint seemed imminent, particularly after the
of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro.
With Maduro set to be sworn in for a third term, Medina, 43, made a difficult decision: to flee his home in Venezuela for the relative safety of Bogota, the capital of neighbouring Colombia.
â€œBefore they could put me back in prison, I decided to escape,â€ said Medina.
Maduroâ€™s government has long faced criticism for the
of political rivals. But Fridayâ€™s
is set to bring the recent electoral crisis to a head, with observers warning that the violence may escalate as Maduro strives to hold onto power.

â€œThe regime â€Šis going to do everything they can to ensure that Maduro can be re-inaugurated and that he can continue with his administration,â€ said Juan Pappier, deputy director of Human Rights Watchâ€™s Americas division.
â€œIf they see that possibility challenged in any way, for example through [opposition-led] demonstrations, they are going to repress them brutally.â€
Medina remembers his final months in Venezuela as being drenched in fear.
In the lead-up to the controversial election, he had joined the campaign of opposition leader
as a photographer, documenting her efforts to galvanise support for presidential candidate
But that work once again made him a target.
Medina was not unknown to the Maduro government: In 2018, he was arrested on charges of money laundering, criminal association and inciting hate, all of which he denies.
Instead, he maintains his arrest was in retaliation for his reporting on human rights abuses. He was held without trial in the Ramo Verde military prison until January 2020.
â€œThe Venezuelan regime does not tolerate any comments or information against them,â€ he said.
â€œThe media is scared,â€ Medina added. â€œFreedom of expression in Venezuela has been completely lost because journalists inside Venezuela are doing what they can to avoid imprisonment.â€
But the
on July 28, 2024, brought
worse than any Medina had witnessed before.
Hours after polls closed, the National Electoral Council named Maduro the winner, without offering its usual breakdown of voting tallies.
Meanwhile, the opposition published receipts of the votes that instead suggested Gonzalez had won the election with nearly 70 percent of the vote. As
over the alleged electoral fraud, a government crackdown ensued.
As state forces swept the streets for protesters, seizing dissidents from their homes, Medina said he was tipped off that he would be jailed â€” again.

He quickly went into hiding. Medina spent two months holed up in different locations in the capital Caracas, trying to avoid arrest. He said the countryâ€™s intelligence forces had already knocked at the door of his home in the city.
Feeling cornered, Medina decided to flee on September 15 to Bogota, where he has stayed ever since.
As many as 2,500 people were ultimately detained in the post-election protests, according to government statistics.
Another 25 people were killed, in what independent investigators for the United Nations
â€œunprecedented levels of violenceâ€.
A UN fact-finding mission
earlier this month that at least 56 political opposition activists, 10 journalists and one human rights defender were among the arrested between August and December.
On Tuesday, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights also
a report alleging systematic state repression intended â€œto prevent the political participation of the oppositionâ€ and â€œsow terror among citizensâ€.
But in the lead-up to Fridayâ€™s inauguration, more than 1,500 prisoners detained in the post-election sweep
, in what critics say could be an attempt to reduce scrutiny on the governmentâ€™s human rights record.

Alfredo Romero, the director of Foro Penal, a Venezuelan human rights watchdog, explained that â€œhaving a number of innocent youths with their relatives, especially their mothers, at the door of the prisonsâ€ holding vigils was reflecting poorly on the Maduro administration.
Rights groups have also questioned the accuracy of the governmentâ€™s numbers.
Romero said that at least 1,749 prisoners remained in custody as of the first week of January, and more alleged dissidents had since been detained.
â€œPeople may be released from prison, but it doesnâ€™t mean that new ones wonâ€™t be jailed,â€ he said.
Despite widespread fear over repression, demonstrations are expected on the day of Maduroâ€™s third inauguration.
Gonzalez, the oppositionâ€™s presidential candidate, has also pledged to return to Venezuela from his
and be sworn in on Friday. It is unclear how or if he will follow through on that pledge.
In a video message posted to social media on Sunday, Machado, who has remained in hiding in Venezuela for months, called on Venezuelans to march in support of a transition of power this week.

â€œMaduro is not going to leave on his own, we must make him leave with the strength of a population that never gives up,â€ Machado said. â€œIt is time to stand firm and make them understand that this is as far as they go. That this is over.â€
In turn, the Maduro government has ramped up security and deployed more than 1,200 military personnel to cities across the country to â€œguarantee peaceâ€ on inauguration day.

The government has also detained more than 12 human rights defenders, political activists, and relatives of opposition figures in recent days, according to Amnesty International, a human rights organisation.
The detainments allegedly include Gonzalezâ€™s son-in-law, Rafael Tudares: The presidential candidate
Tudares was
in Caracas on Tuesday.
And on Thursday, Machado herself was detained as she left an anti-Maduro protest, according to opposition officials who said her transportation was fired upon. She was swiftly released.
The recent arrests have prompted a new swell of international condemnation.
The United States Embassy in Venezuela has
the detention of Gonzalezâ€™s son-in-law an act of â€œintimidationâ€ against the opposition. Colombian President Gustavo Petro
that the arrests prevented him from attending Maduroâ€™s inauguration on Friday.
Still, Maduroâ€™s control of state institutions has allowed security forces to act with impunity, according to the recent
from the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights.
Medina himself believes repression in Venezuela may escalate if Maduro remains in power for a third term.

â€œIf we do not achieve freedom, there will be much more persecution,â€ said Medina. â€œThey will try to put an end to everything that they consider the opposition, including political leaders and the media.â€
For now, he added that he hopes to continue his work exposing human rights abuses from abroad.
â€œWhat I have decided is that, no matter what, Iâ€™ll fight for my country.â€
article.desc: On Friday, Maduro is set to start a third term. Will his inauguration continue his post-election crackdown on dissent?
article.summary: Jesus Medina Ezaine had already spent 16 months in a Venezuelan military prison . The 43-year-old was arrested on charges of money laundering, criminal association and inciting hate . He was held without trial in the Ramo Verde military prison until January 2020 . Medina says his arrest was in retaliation for his reporting on human rights abuses. â€œThe Venezuelan regime does not tolerate any comments or information against them. The media is scared,ï¿½

article.title: Croatiaâ€™s incumbent Milanovic expected to win presidential run-off election
content: Croatians are voting in a presidential run-off election, with incumbent Zoran Milanovic expected to win a second term in office in what would be a blow to the ruling Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) party, which backs his rival.
Polling stations opened on Sunday at 7am local time (06:00 GMT) and would close at about 7pm (18:00 GMT), with exit polls expected minutes later.

Milanovic, an outspoken critic of Western military support for Ukraine against Russia, won 49.1 percent of the vote during the contestâ€™s first round two weeks ago â€“ narrowly missing an outright victory.

The 58-year-old leader entered the contest with surging momentum as he faced off against Dragan Primorac, who managed to garner 19.35 percent of the votes. Primorac, 59, is backed by the HDZ party, which has governed the former Yugoslav republic since declaring independence in 1991.
The
comes as the European Union and NATO member country of 3.8 million people struggles with biting inflation, corruption scandals and a labour shortage.
Milanovic, a former left-wing prime minister, took over the presidency in 2020 with the backing of the main opposition Social Democrats (SDP) party.
Milanovic condemned Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine but has also criticised the Westâ€™s military support for Kyiv. His main rival has dubbed him â€œa pro-Russian puppetâ€.
He is very popular and is sometimes compared with United States President-elect Donald Trump for his combative style of communication with political opponents.
The 58-year-old has been a fierce critic of current Prime Minister Andrej Plenkovic and the pair have long sparred with each other.
The incumbent president regularly accuses Plenkovic and his conservative HDZ party of systemic corruption, calling the prime minister a â€œserious threat to Croatiaâ€™s democracyâ€.
Croatiaâ€™s presidential powers are limited, but a win by Milanovic would be a setback for the HDZ and Prime Minister Plenkovic.
An elected president holds political authority and acts as the supreme military commander.Â Many believe the presidential position is key for the political balance of power.

Primorac entered politics in the early 2000s when he was the science and education minister in the HDZ-led government. He unsuccessfully ran for the presidency in 2009, and after that mainly focused on his academic career, including lecturing at universities in the US, China and Croatia.
Milanovic denied he is pro-Russian but last year blocked the dispatch of five Croatian officers to NATOâ€™s mission in Germany called Security Assistance and Training for Ukraine.
He also pledged he would never approve sending Croatian soldiers as part of any NATO mission to Ukraine. Plenkovic and his government say there is no such proposal.
Milanovic accused Primorac of associating with â€œmass murderersâ€, referring to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s associates and the war in Gaza.
article.desc: Zoran Milanovic, a NATO critic, is on track to win the run-off vote after securing 49 percent votes in round one.
article.summary: Croatians are voting in a presidential run-off election, with incumbent Zoran Milanovic expected to win a second term in office . The 58-year-old leader entered the contest with surging momentum as he faced off against Dragan Primorac, who managed to garner 19.35 percent of the votes . Milanovic is a fierce critic of current Prime Minister Andrej Plenkovic. His main rival has dubbed him.

content: Here is the
on Sunday, January 12:

The article was published on January 12, 2014, at the time of the first day of this year's edition . It is the second time the world has been published in the same month of the year. article.title: Chadâ€™s ruling party wins majority in controversial parliamentary election
content: Chadâ€™s governing party has taken the majority of seats in last monthâ€™s
that was mostly boycotted by opposition parties, according to provisional results.

President Mahamat Idriss Debyâ€™s party, the Patriotic Salvation Movement, has secured 124 of the 188 seats at the National Assembly, Ahmed Bartchiret, head of the electoral commission, announced late on Saturday.
The participation rate was put at 51.56 percent, which opposition parties said showed voter doubts about the validity of the contest.
The December 29 election was presented by Debyâ€™s party as the last stage of the countryâ€™s transition to democracy after he took power as a military ruler in 2021.
The takeover followed the
of Debyâ€™s father and longtime President Idriss Deby Itno, who spent three decades in power. Mahamat Deby eventually won last yearâ€™s disputed
The vote, which also included municipal and regional elections, was Chadâ€™s first in more than a decade.

Deby had said the election would â€œpave the way for the era of decentralisation so long-awaited and desired by the Chadian peopleâ€, referring to the distribution of power beyond the national government to the various provincial and municipal levels.
The election was boycotted by more than 10 opposition parties, including the main Transformers party, whose candidate, Succes Masra, came second in the presidential election.
The main opposition had called the election a â€œcharadeâ€ and expressed worries that it would be a repeat of the presidential vote, which election observers said was not credible.
Last monthâ€™s vote came at a critical period for Chad, which is battling several security challenges â€“ from attacks in the Lake Chad region by the Boko Haram armed group to
with France, its former colonial power.

The severing of military ties echoes recent moves by Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso, which all kicked out French troops and fostered closer ties with Russia after a string of coups in West and Central Africaâ€™s Sahel region.
This week, security forces
on the presidency that the government referred to as a â€œdestabilisation attemptâ€.
article.desc: Electoral body says President Mahamat Idriss Debyâ€™s party secured 124 of 188 National Assembly seats in vote boycotted by opposition.
article.summary: President Mahamat Idriss Debyâ€™s party, the Patriotic Salvation Movement, has secured 124 of the 188 seats at the National Assembly . The vote, which also included municipal and regional elections, was Chad's first in more than a decade . The takeover followed the of Deby's father and longtime President IdrISS Deby Itno, who spent three decades in power. The main opposition had called

article.title: Activists back US professor â€˜forcedâ€™ from Columbia over Palestine advocacy
content: Academics, lawyers and activists have voiced support for a law professor who says she was pressured to leave
for her advocacy for pro-Palestinian students.

â€œEffective today, I have reached an agreement with Columbia University that relieves me of my obligations to teach or participate in faculty governance after serving on the Columbia law faculty for 25 years,â€ Katherine Franke, a tenured law professor at the Ivy League university in the United States, said in
on Thursday.
â€œWhile the university may call this change in my status â€œretirement,â€ it should be more accurately understood as a termination dressed up in more palatable terms.

â€œI have come to the view that the Columbia University administration has created such a toxic and hostile environment for legitimate debate around the war in Israel and Palestine that I can no longer teach or conduct research,â€ Franke said.

Protests against Israelâ€™s war on Gaza erupted on Columbiaâ€™s New York City campus last April and inspired similar encampments at other institutions across the US and beyond. Students demanded that the university divest from Israel, which has been accused of war crimes and genocide in Gaza. They also called for a ceasefire to end the war that has killed more than 46,000 Palestinians and turned Gaza into rubble.
The prestigious Ivy League school, however, attempted to push back against the studentsâ€™ protests â€“ a crackdown that brought criticisms from rights organisations.

Some critics argued that the crackdown on pro-Palestinian students and groups put a damper on free speech on the college campus, while others allege the university administration has allowed a hostile atmosphere to thrive.

Commenting on Frankeâ€™s resignation on Saturday, Francesca Albanese, the United Nations special rapporteur on the occupied Palestinian territories, said Franke has become â€œanother victim of the pro-Israelism that is turning universities, and other spaces of public life, into places of obscurantism, discrimination and oppressionâ€.
On Sunday, Noura Erakat, a professor at Rutgers University and human rights lawyer, called the universityâ€™s mistreatment of Professor Franke â€œegregiousâ€.

â€œShe has resigned after 25 years of an illustrious academic career and commitment to her students because she decided there is nothing to return to â€“ it is far too hostile,â€ Erakat posted on the social media platform X.

Todd Wolfson, the president of the American Association of University Professors (AAUP), described Columbiaâ€™s actions as â€œtruly shamefulâ€ and said on Saturday that the AAUP stands with â€œProfessor Franke and against this repression of pro-Palestinian speechâ€.

The Center for Constitutional Rights, an advocacy organisation, said on Thursday that Frankeâ€™s resignation represents â€œan egregious attack on both academic freedom and Palestinian rights advocacyâ€.
According to a New York Times

, Columbia University spokesperson Samantha Slater said that a complaint had been filed [against Franke] â€œalleging discriminatory harassment in violation of our policies. An investigation was conducted, and a finding was issued.â€

In her resignation statement, Franke noted how last February, two of her colleagues filed a complaint against her with the universityâ€™s Office of Equal Opportunity and Affirmative Action, charging that one of her comments to US news outlet Democracy Now! amounted to harassment of Israeli members of the Columbia community in violation of university policies.
In a January 2024

, Franke had spoken about the universityâ€™s graduate-programme relationship with countries including Israel and said: â€œItâ€™s something that many of us were concerned about, because so many of those Israeli students, who then come to the Columbia campus, are coming right out of their military service. And theyâ€™ve been known to harass Palestinian and other students on our campus.â€

As the investigation of complaints against this comment progressed, Franke said that in April 2024 during a US congressional hearing, Congresswoman Elise Stefanik asked then-Columbia President Minouche Shafik what disciplinary actions had been taken against Franke, who had commented on Israeli students on campus.
Stefanik wrongly attributed the remark â€œall Israeli students who served in the [Israeli army] are dangerous and shouldnâ€™t be on campusâ€ to Franke.
â€œPresident Shafik responded â€˜I agree with you that those comments are completely unacceptable and discriminatory.â€™
Professor Franke says she faced harassment, including death threats, following the Congressional hearing.
Shafik, who was criticised for the handling of the studentsâ€™ protests, stepped down as the university president in August.

Meanwhile, an external law firm was later hired to investigate Frankeâ€™s comments last November and concluded that her remarks had violated the universityâ€™s Equal Opportunity and Affirmative Action policies. Franke has said she has filed an appeal.
â€œUpon reflection, it became clear to me that Columbia had become such a hostile environment, that I could no longer serve as an active member of the faculty,â€ Franke said in her statement.

â€œRather than defend the role of a university in a democracy, in fostering critical debate, research, and learning around matters of vital public concern â€¦ Columbia Universityâ€™s leadership has demonstrated a willingness to collaborate with the very enemies of our academic mission.â€
article.desc: Katherine Franke, a law professor at the university, says she was forced to retire over her views critical of Israelâ€™s treatment of Palestinians.
article.summary: Katherine Franke, a tenured law professor at the Ivy League university in the United States, says she was pressured to leave for her advocacy for pro-Palestinian students . She says she has reached an agreement with Columbia University that relieves me of my obligations to teach or participate in faculty governance after serving on the Columbia law faculty. The Ivy League school attempted to push back against the students' protests. Protests against Israelâ€™s war

article.title: Sudan army says its forces enter Wad Madani in push to retake city from RSF
content: The Sudanese military and allied armed groups have entered Wad Madani, pushing out the rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary from the strategic city in Gezira state, according to the army.
In a statement on Saturday, the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) â€œcongratulatedâ€ people on â€œour forces entering the city of Wad Madani this morningâ€ after more than a year of RSF control.
â€œThey are now working to clean up the remaining rebel pockets inside the city,â€ the statement said.
The office of SAF-allied government spokesperson and Information and Culture Minister Khalid al-Aiser said the army had â€œliberatedâ€ the city.
The army posted a video that appears to show soldiers inside the city the RSF had held since December 2023.
In a speech shared on Telegram, Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the RSF leader widely known as Hemedti, acknowledged defeat but insisted that the battle was not over.
â€œWe lost Wad Madani, but we will reclaim it. People just need to regroup, reorganise and reassess themselves,â€ he said.
Hemedti attributed the defeat to what he described as the armyâ€™s reliance on Iranian drones and fighters from Ethiopiaâ€™s Tigray region.

The SAF and the RSF have been at war since April 2023, causing what the United Nations calls the worldâ€™s worst displacement crisis and declarations of famine in parts of the Northeast African country.
Wad Madani is strategic because it is a crossroads of key supply highways linking several states, and is the nearest key city to the capital, Khartoum.
Al Jazeeraâ€™s Hiba Morgan, reporting from Khartoum, said the SAF had been advancing towards the city in recent days.

â€œThey have been taking over villages in the south and southeast of the [Gezira] state until this morning when they took over Hantoub Bridge â€“ a decisive bridge that leads into the city,â€ she said.
â€œThe army is now in most parts of Wad Madani,â€ Morgan added.
â€œThe army and allied fighters have spread out around us across the cityâ€™s streets,â€ one witness told the AFP news agency from his home in central Wad Madani, requesting anonymity for his safety.
Both the SAF and the RSF have been accused of committing war crimes, including targeting civilians and indiscriminately shelling residential areas.
The paramilitary forces have been accused of summary killings, rampant looting, systematic sexual violence and laying siege to entire towns.
The United States on Tuesday
the RSF had â€œcommitted genocideâ€ and imposed sanctions on its leader Hemedti.

The local resistance committee, one of hundreds of pro-democracy volunteer groups across the country coordinating front-line aid, hailed the Wad Madani advance as an end to â€œthe tyrannyâ€ of the RSF.
Witnesses in SAF-controlled cities across Sudan reported dozens of people taking to the streets to celebrate the news.

The recapture of Gezira as a whole could mark a turning point in the war that began over disputes on the integration of the two forces. Since then, tens of thousands of people have been killed and some 12 million displaced, creating one of the worldâ€™s largest humanitarian crises.
In the early months of the war, more than half a million people had sought shelter in Gezira, before a lightning RSF offensive displaced upwards of 300,000 in December 2023, according to the UN.
Most have since been repeatedly displaced as the feared paramilitaries moved further south.
The RSF still holds the rest of the central agricultural state of Gezira, as well as nearly all of Sudanâ€™s western Darfur region and swaths of the countryâ€™s south.
The army controls the north and east, as well as parts of Khartoum.
article.desc: The military says it is working to â€˜clean up the remaining rebel pocketsâ€™ inside the capital of Gezira state.
article.summary: Sudanese military and allied armed groups have entered Wad Madani, pushing out the rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary from the strategic city in Gezira state, according to the army . The SAF and the RSF have been at war since April 2023, causing what the United Nations calls the world's worst displacement crisis and declarations of famine in parts of the Northeast African country. WadMadani is the nearest key city.
